content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

I already validated, but I think you should highlight the part saying that an atom is up to two letters long.
Trailing zeros are significant figures there (3 digit precision) so it makes sense to keep them, well played.
"multiplied by its coefficient", it's not a coefficient, it's the number of atoms of this kind in this molecule.
Unihedron said that he doesn't know what 10^23, you can provide a short text saying that it's 6023 billion of billions times a grain of rice (enough to provide food for all the earth for years)

Tho, it's interesting to put this background about what is a mole, but it's totally useless for the game.
Also, due to the lack of that information in test cases it's basically unrealistic for reverse mode.

not as simple as it might seem ... but solvable in 5 minutes

i like this one

You don't need to know what is a mole and what quantity it represents to complete the exercise. This text is here only to give a little background for the exercise. But  this constant is used nowhere.

Saying that a mole is 6,023.10^23 of an element is the same of saying that a pair is 2 elements. It's just another word used to describe that quantity.
Thank you for your comments. I updated everything as you suggested. And btw, I learn the syntax for highlighting. :D

Hello, I'm mostly targetting about the way the number is written. I looked up the number (apparently it's called the "Avogadro constant" which was 6.022*10^23) and the use of commas makes the number appear to be 6023.1^23 because of the way the comma differs from how numbers are written in English (with the decimal point using the period and the thousand break being a comma). As it is, I think the number should be written as either 6.023×10^23 (which is also how it is on wikipedia) or shorthand science notation as 6.023e23.
Yes ! You're right. I'm sorry, Wikipedia in my language uses comma in the opposite meaning of English. You're totally right, I corrected.

I don't know what a mole is and what any of your text was trying to say, nor do I have any knowledge in chemistry. Needless to say, I had no idea how to solve your clash proposal and I doubt any reasonable programmer would be expected to solve this in reverse mode.
Sorry, just to make sure, you do realize you're submitting this as a clash proposal for reverse mode enabled, right?

I don't have any knowledge also in chemistry beyond the little taught in high school. But I understand that the exercise can look pretty intimidating. If it can helps, I can add tests with only one atom, so the input and the output will be identical.

If you think atoms as variables in an equation, then the problem becomes nothing more than solving an equation with x, y, etc given.
Yes, I know it, but if it is too complicated, then I'll uncheck it without any problem. :)
I don't disagree that you can figure out the constant by studying the numbers, but when the values are not with exact precision this won't work.

You don't need the constant. I wrote a few words about it to give a background. But it comes nowhere in the resolution.

Let's replace mole by pair and atom by variables. You have x = 12.011, y = 15.999 and I ask you for x.2y and I want the result to be in pair. The result will then be 44.009 pairs. Nothing more. You never used the fact that a pair is 2 elements.

Is it better for you ? Do you see the point ?

Thanks for all your comments because I see that my exercise lacks of clarity. :)

I don't think your exercise lacks clarity. What I'm targetting right now is that it's marked for reverse mode, and with all reverse proposals I try to solve the problem without looking at the description, since this is what users are expected to do in a real clash fight.

What strikes me as a bit confusing is that when the description is not there this appears as a chameleon problem - I'm getting the impression that I was required to convert the format into a new value (since there exists a unit). After a bit of tinkering with my code I managed to fix my bug of treating all letters as independent and it does work (so it id have a simple solution and was not what I was assuming - that a more difficult formula was in place). So here are some new notes:

1. The output format having a unit was mildly confusing, for inputs which had implied units of unknown form.
2. Validator 3's expected output has a trailing 0, which is not tested for in sample test cases. You need more tests or for that to be swapped into a visible test, otherwise it is impossible to account for when that's not met yet and the sample tests still pass.
3. This is just a nitpick at this point and I don't really mind if it's not changed but it might be more straightforward to put the formula line (CO2) above all else to distinguish it from the catalogue. Like this:
CO2
2
C 12.011
O 15.999

A big thanks for all your suggestions. Indeed, that story of mole in the output is confusing, so I'm going to delete it. It is not useful, so I don't want people to get confused.

I'll also swap the two tests with the trailing 0 and add some more, so there is no ambiguity possible. Thanks again for your help! :)

Why 6.023e23 and not 6.022e23 though?
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avogadro_constant

"6.023e23 times (the Avogadro constant) of an element, or 6023 billion of billions times"
You are off by a factor of 100 here.
That's because I recopy the constant with a mistake. Thanks for reporting.
